chapters.content:
This is a BEmONC Signal Function as stated by the United Nations. However, you still have to act according to government law in your country and should only perform procedures that you have been authorized for. The Golden Minute: By one minute of age all newborns should be able to breathe on their own or should be ventilated with a bag and a mask.

Assess the newborn within the first ½ minute of life.

Resuscitate if the newborn is gasping or not crying or breathing.

Dry and stimulate, if not born in thick meconium.

If solid meconium: clear mouth and nose and suction airways before stimulating.

If not breathing after ½ minute:

CALL FOR HELP!

Clamp and cut the umbilical cord and do the following:

Airway

Position the head in neutral position.

Position mask so it covers mouth and nose, use the “C” and “E” grip.

Give 5 slow inflation breaths each lasting 2-3 seconds.

Observe that chest is moving. If not moving, check the positioning of the head and the mask.

Consider performing jawthrust.

Oxygen supplement is not necessary.

Breathing

If breathing is still insufficient or heart rate is below 100 beats per minute;

Give ventilation breaths at a rate of 40/minute.

Observe chest is moving. If not go back to Airway.

Assess breathing and heart rate every minute.

If breathing is still insufficient or heart rate is below 100 continue ventilation breaths.

Do not refer if emergency is not controlled!

Never refer a patient with uncontrolled bleeding, retained placenta, uncontrolled hypertension, unevacuated septic or haemorrhagic abortion or septic shock.

Remove placenta by trained provider.

In cases of prolonged labour:
- If at a peripheral facility, refer the woman to a higher centre with her partograph for further management.

- At a referral facility, amniotomy may be done (also for HIV+ women if on antiretroviral therapy). Reassess in 2 hours and decide on further management if there is insufficient progress.

After emergency management and when in a stable condition, discuss decision of referral with woman and relatives.

Quickly organise transport and possible financial aid.

Inform the referral center.

Accompany the woman.

It is crucial that she is accompanied by a health worker who is trained in delivery care and able to manage an emergency situation, if it recurrs during transport.

Consider to bring a relative who can donate blood.

Bring

Referral note.

Essential emergency drugs:

  • Oxytocin and Ergometrine (alternatively Misoprostol) for treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
  • Oxytocin for IM injection immediately postpartum
  • Hydralazine for IV treatment of elevated blood pressure
  • Magnesium Sulphate for eclampsia
  • Calcium Gluconate for intoxication with Magnesium Sulphate
  • Ampicillin for infections
  • Diazepam for pain relief

Supplies:

  • Delivery set
  • Towels
  • IV-equipment + IV fluids
  • Foetoscope or Doppler
  • Blood pressure monitor
  • Ambu bag
  • Suction bulb

During Transport

Observe vital signs and level of consciousness.

If pregnant check FHR.

In case of excessive vaginal bleeding apply bimanual compression.

If the bleeding does not stop apply aorta compression (can be maintained up to 6 hours).

If the woman’s condition permits:

Keep record of all IV fluids, medications given, time of administration and the woman´s condition.

If in labour during transport:

FHR every half an hour.

If pushing and superficial breathing is not enough to repress this urge, stop the transport and deliver the woman.

drugDetails.content:
Indications and Usage

Ampicillin is a B-lactamantibiotics effective on gram positive as well as negative bacterial infections.

Dosage and Administration

Adults:

1 g intravenously every 6 hours (at sepsis initially each 4 hours).

Children:

First week of life:

50 mg/kg per dose every 12 hours intravenously or intramuscularly.

Week 2-4 of life:

50 mg/kg per dose every 8 hours intravenously or intramuscularly.

Contraindications

Allergy to penicillin.

Adverse Reactions

Common adverse reactions are diarrhea and skin rash.

Uncommon reactions are nausea, vomiting, stomatitis, glossitis, pseudomembraneous colitis, lowered platelets, anemia and urticaria.

Anaphylactic shock is rare.

Indications and usage

Treatment of bacterial infections. Alternative to penicillin at allergy to penicillin.

Dosage and administration

Adults:

1-2 grams intravenously or intramuscular once daily.

Children:

For meningitis:

50 mg/kg per dose every 12 hours intravenously or 100 mg/kg per dose once every day intravenously or intramuscularly

For pus draining from the eye:

50 mg/kg/dose once intramuscularly (max 125 mg)

Contraindications

Allergy to cephalosporins. Severe reactions to penicillin (anaphylactic reactions)

Neonates ( ≤ 28 days):
Hyperbilirubinemic neonates, especially prematures, should not be treated with ceftriaxone.

In vitro studies have shown that ceftriaxone can displace bilirubin from its binding to serum albumin, leading to a possible risk of bilirubin encephalopathy in these patients.

Ceftriaxone is contraindicated in neonates if they require (or are expected to require) treatment with calcium-containing IV solutions, including continuous calcium-containing infusions such as parenteral nutrition because of the risk of precipitation of ceftriaxone-calcium.

Adverse reactions

Common adverse reactions are nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, skin rash, and itching.

Uncommon reactions are headache, dizziness, and urticaria.

Rare reactions are lowered platelets, necrosis of the skin, drug fever, candidiasis, hemolytic anemia and hearing loss.

Indications and Usage

Aminoglycoside antibiotic indicated for treatment of severe or serious bacterial infections in adults and children.

Dosage and Administration

Adults:

240 mg intravenously once a day.

Children (First week of life):

2.5 mg per kg every 12 hours if term; 1.5 mg per kg every 12 hours if preterm intravenously or intramuscularly.

Treat for at least two days.

Children (Weeks 2-4 of life):

7.5 mg/kg per dose once a day intravenously or intramuscularly.

Contraindications

Allergy to aminoglycosides.

Treatment should not be more than 3 days if the patient is suffering from renal failure (oliguria or elevated creatinine).

Adverse Reactions

Common adverse reactions are kidney affection, hearing loss, and tinnitus.

Uncommon reactions are liver affection, increased or lowered blood pressure, respiratory depression, lowered platelets, joint and muscle pain, depression, coordination disturbances, skin rash, itching, visual disturbances, urticaria and anaphylactic reactions.

Rare reactions are deafness, hair loss, low urine production and necrosis of the skin.

Indications and Usage

Phenobarbital is in a group of drugs called barbiturates.

Phenobarbital slows the activity of the brain and nervous system.

Phenobarbital is used to treat or prevent seizures.

Observe closely for apnoea and always have a bag-mask available to ventilate the child if necessary.

Be aware that the plasma half-life for Phenobarbital in children and newborns (less than 48 hours old) ranges between 60 to 180 hours with a mean of 110 hours.

Dosage and Administration

Children:

For seizures:

Start treatment with loading dose 20 mg/kg intravenously over 15 minutes or as a single dose intramuscularly if IV access is not established.

If convulsions do not stop within 30 minutes give further dose of phenobarbital 10 mg/kg IV slowly over five minutes (or IM.).

Repeat one more time after another 30 minutes, if necessary.

Maximum dose is of 40 mg/kg body weight.

If needed continue Phenobarbital at maintenance dose of 5 mg/kg per day.

CAUTION:

Diazepam given in addition to phenobarbital will increase the risk of circulatory collapse and respiratory failure.

Contraindications

Phenobarbital is contraindicated in patients who are hypersensitive to barbiturates, in patients with a history of manifest or latent porphyria, and in patients with marked impairment of liver function or respiratory disease in which dyspnoea or obstruction is evident.

Adverse reactions

Common:

The most common adverse reaction, estimated to occur at a rate of 1 to 3 patients per 100, are disorders of the nervous system such as drowsiness or sleepiness.

Less common:

Adverse reactions estimated to occur at a rate of less than 1 in 100 patients are listed below, grouped by organ system and by decreasing order of occurrence:

Nervous System:

Agitation, confusion, hyperkinesia, ataxia, CNS depression, nightmares, nervousness, psychiatric disturbance, hallucinations, insomnia, anxiety, dizziness, abnormality in thinking.

Respiratory System:

Hypoventilation, apnoea.

Cardiovascular System:

Bradycardia, hypotension, syncope.

Digestive System:

Nausea, vomiting, constipation.

Other Reported Reactions:

Headache, injection site reactions, hypersensitivity reactions (angioedoema, skin rashes, exfoliative dermatitis), fever, liver damage, megaloblastic anaemia following chronic Phenobarbital use.

questions.question: Failure to initiate adequate breathing at birth is a common cause of:
questions.description: Failure to initiate adequate breathing at birth is a common cause of all of the above, therefore all answers are correct.

answers.value: Stillbirth
Neonatal death
Disability
All answers are correct

questions.question: The golden minute implies that all newborns should by one minute of age:
questions.description:
The golden minute implies that all newborns should by one minute of age:

Breathe on their own.

If not breathing be ventilated with a bag and a mask.

answers.value: Breathe on their own
Move their arms and legs with a good tone
If not breathing be ventilated with a bag and a mask
Lie skin to skin with the mother

keyLearningPointDetails.description: NR - Assess the newborn after birth

questions.question: When do you assess a newborn after birth?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/brand_new_baby
questions.description: You assess a newborn immediately after delivery.

answers.value: Immediately after delivery
After one minute
After the umbilical cord is cut
If it is not crying

questions.question: Where do you place the newborn immediately after birth?
questions.description: Immediately after birth you place the newborn on the mother with skin to skin contact.

answers.value: On the mother with skin to skin contact
Set it down in between the legs of the mother while you care for her
On the weighing scale
In a warm cloth away from the mother

questions.question: What is the first steps you take after the baby is born?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/brand_new_baby
questions.description: The first steps you take after the newborn is born is to sssess whether the newborn is crying or breathing.

answers.value: Assess whether the newborn is crying or breathing
Suction the baby’s mouth and nose
Start inflation breaths with a ventilation bag
Call for help

questions.question: Which statement is true?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/green_newborn
questions.description: If a baby is born with thick meconium, do not begin by stimulating the baby. Instead, first clear the airway by suction the mouth and nose.

answers.value: If a baby is born with thick meconium, do not begin by stimulating the baby. Instead, first clear the airway by suction the mouth and nose
Suction ALL newborns at birth

questions.question: If a baby is born with thick meconium, in what order would you act?
questions.description:
If a baby is born with thick meconium, you act in following order:

Clear the airway by suction the mouth and nose.

answers.value: Clear the airway by suction the mouth and nose.
Stimulate the newborn

questions.question: What do you do within 5 seconds after the delivery of a vigorous newborn?
questions.description:
Within 5 seconds after the delivery you:

Dry the baby with a towel. 

Stimulate the baby by rubbing the back.

Remove wet towels and cover the newborn to keep it warm.

answers.value: Dry the baby with a towel
Stimulate the baby by rubbing the back
Cut the umbilical cord
Remove wet towels and cover the newborn to keep it warm

keyLearningPointDetails.description: NR - Newborn is not breathing well

questions.question: Immediately after birth you find that the newborn is not breathing well. What do you do next?
questions.description: If immediately after birth you find that the newborn is not breathing well, you stimulate the baby by drying and rubbing the back with a dry cloth.

answers.value: Stimulate the baby by drying and rubbing the back with a dry cloth
Suction the baby’s mouth and nose
Assess the baby’s heart rate

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true? The newborn needs resuscitation using bag and mask if:
questions.description: The newborn needs resuscitation using bag and mask if, within 30 seconds after delivery and after thorough stimulation it is gasping or not crying or breathing.

answers.value: Within 30 seconds after delivery and after thorough stimulation it is gasping or not crying or breathing
Within 2 minutes after delivery it is gasping or not crying or not breathing

questions.question: The newborn is not responding to stimulation by drying and rubbing the back. Place the following four immediate actions in order:
questions.description:
The newborn is not responding to stimulation by drying and rubbing the back, your actions should be:

1. Call for help
2. Clamp and cut the umbilical cord
3. Open the airway or position the head in neutral position 
4. Give 5 inflation breaths

answers.value: Call for help
Clamp and cut the umbilical cord
Open the airway or position the head in neutral position
Give 5 inflation breaths

questions.question: When performing resuscitation with bag and mask, what is the correct head position?
questions.description: The correct head position is when the head is parallel to the surface.

answers.value: Head is parallel to the surface with a rolled towel under the shoulders.
Head is bent forward to open the airway
Head is to the side to let fluids escape

questions.question: Where do you place the mask on the newborn?
questions.description: You place the mask on the mouth and nose.

answers.value: On the mouth and nose
On the mouth
On the nose
On the eyes, mouth and nose

questions.question: How do you ensure that ventilation is effective?
questions.description: You ensure that ventilation is effective be making sure that the chest rises with every ventilation.

answers.value: Make sure that the chest rises with every ventilation
Make sure that the bag is emptied every breath
Make sure to press very hard on the bag
Make sure to ventilate very fast

questions.question: You start resuscitation by giving how many inflation breaths?
questions.description: You start resuscitation by giving 5 inflation breaths.

questions.question: How do you perform a jaw thrust?
questions.description: You perform a jaw thrust by lifting the baby’s jaw forward with one hand.

answers.value: Lift the baby’s jaw forward with one hand
Apply force on the mask on the newborn’s jaw
Apply force on the mask on the newborn’s jaw

questions.question: The chest is not rising during your attempts to provide inflation breaths. What do you do?
questions.description:
If the chest is not rising during your attempts to provide inflation breaths you:

Reposition the head and lift the newborn’s jaw forward.

Give 5 inflation breaths again.

answers.value: Stop resuscitation
Wait and see if the respiration is restored spontaneously
Reposition the head and lift the newborn’s jaw forward
Give 5 inflation breaths again

questions.question: What are inflation breaths?
questions.description: Inflation breaths are the first 5 slow ventilations in neonatal resuscitation – each breath is sustained for 2-3 seconds while the chest moves.

answers.value: The first 5 slow ventilations in neonatal resuscitation – each breath is sustained for 2-3 seconds while the chest moves.
Ventilating the newborn with at a rate of 40 breaths per minute– with each breath you say “breathe-2-3”.
The first spontaneous breaths the newborn takes unassisted on its own.

questions.question: What are ventilation breaths?
questions.description: Ventilation breaths are ventilating the newborn at a rate of 40 breaths per minute– with each breath you say “breathe-2-3”.

answers.value: Ventilating the newborn at a rate of 40 breaths per minute– with each breath you say “breathe-2-3”
The first 5 slow ventilations in neonatal resuscitation – each breath is sustained for 2-3 seconds while the chest moves
The first spontaneous breaths the newborn takes unassisted on its own

questions.question: At what rate do you give ventilation breaths with?
questions.description: You give ventilation breaths with approximately 40 breaths per minute.

answers.value: Approximately 40 breaths per minute
Approximately 100 breaths per minute

questions.question: After inflation breaths, the newborn is breathing less than 30 breaths/minute, or the heart rate is below 100 beats per min. What is your next action?
questions.description:
If after inflation breaths, the newborn is breathing less than 30 breaths/minute, or the heart rate is below 100 beats per min. -
 you start ventilation breaths.

answers.value: You start ventilation breaths
Wait and see if the respiration is restored spontaneously
Stimulation by drying and rubbing the back.
Stop resuscitation and counsel the mother on her loss

questions.question: When do you continue with ventilation breaths?
questions.description:
You continue with ventilation breaths when:

Respiratory rate less than 30 times/minute.

Heart rate below 100 beats per minute.

answers.value: Respiratory rate less than 30 times/minute
Reduced tone
Respiratory rate more than 40 times/minute
Heart rate below 100 beats per minute

questions.question: What is most important thing to keep in mind regarding ventilation breaths?
questions.description: It is most important thing to keep in mind that you know the ventilation technique is effective when you can see chest movements.

answers.value: That the rate is 40 breaths/min
That you know the ventilation technique is effective when you can see chest movements
That you apply force on the mask to ensure a good seal
That you wrap the newborn in a warm cloth

questions.question: How do you ensure an even rhythm in ventilation breaths?
questions.description:
You do following to ensure an even rhythm in ventilation breaths:

Count out loud: “Breathe—two—three” as you ventilate the newborn.

Squeeze the bag as you say “breathe” and release the pressure on the bag as you say “two—three.”

answers.value: Squeeze the bag three times every time you say “breathe - two – three”
Count out loud: “Breathe—two—three” as you ventilate the newborn
Squeeze the bag as you say “breathe” and release the pressure on the bag as you say “two—three.”

questions.question: How do you correctly ventilate a newborn?
questions.description:
You correctly ventilate a newborn by:

Make sure that the mask is well sealed to the newborn.

Look for adequate chest rise.

Allow the lungs to recover between each inflation.

answers.value: Make sure that the mask is well sealed to the newborn
Look for adequate chest rise
Allow the lungs to recover between each inflation
Make sure the newborn has a gastric tube

questions.question: When do you assess the newborn during resuscitation?
questions.description: You assess the newborn during resuscitation every 30 seconds.

answers.value: Every minute
Every 30 seconds
Every 5 minutes
After 20 minutes

questions.question: What do you assess during neonatal resuscitation?
questions.description:
During neonatal resuscitation you assess:

Breathing.

Heart rate.

answers.value: Breathing
If the newborn urinates
Heart rate

questions.question: If the newborn has not established regular breathing or the pulse is below 100 what do you do?
questions.description: If the newborn has not established regular breathing or the pulse is below 100 you continue ventilation breaths.

answers.value: Continue ventilation breaths and prepare for referral or specialist care
Give chest compressions
Stop resuscitation
Wait and see if the respiration is restored spontaneously

questions.question: When the newborn is breathing well, and a heart rate above 100 bpm, in what order would you do the following actions?
questions.description:
You do the following actions:

1. Stop ventilation and continue observation for 5 minutes.

2. Place the newborn skin by skin with the mother 

3. Establish early breastfeeding

4. Every 15 minutes for the first 2 hours, you check breathing, heart rate, and that the newborn is warm.

answers.value: Stop ventilation and continue observation for 5 minutes.
Place the newborn skin by skin with the mother
Establish early breastfeeding
Every 15 minutes for the first 2 hours, you check breathing, heart rate, and that the newborn is warm

questions.question: If the newborn’s colour is bluish or if the newborn is having difficulty breathing with in-drawings or grunting what do you do?
questions.description: If the newborn’s colour is bluish or if the newborn is having difficulty breathing with in-drawings or grunting you give oxygen by nasal catheter or prongs if available.

answers.value: Give oxygen by nasal catheter or prongs if available
Give Phenobarbital IV/IM
Wrap the newborn and give it to the mother

questions.question: When do you stop resuscitation?
questions.description:
You stop resuscitation:

When the newborn is breathing well, it has normal colour, normal tone, and a heart rate above 100 bpm.

If the newborn is not breathing and has no heart rate after 10 min of EFFECTIVE ventilation.

If the newborn has a heart rate below 60 bpm for more than 20 minutes you may take the difficult decision to stop the resuscitation.

answers.value: When the newborn is breathing well, it has normal colour, normal tone, and a heart rate above 100 bpm
If the newborn is not breathing and has no heart rate after 10 min of EFFECTIVE ventilation
If the newborn has a heart rate below 60 bpm for more than 20 minutes you may take the difficult decision to stop the resuscitation.
If the newborn is not breathing and has no pulse after 2 min of EFFECTIVE ventilation

questions.question: You have stopped the resuscitation. What do you do next?
questions.description:
When you have stopped the resuscitation you:

Explain gently to the mother, that the newborn unfortunately did not survive.

Provide emotional support to the family.

answers.value: Explain gently to the mother, that the newborn unfortunately did not survive
Provide emotional support to the family
You leave the woman alone to grieve
You continue with your other duties

keyLearningPointDetails.description: NR - Skin to skin and breastfeeding

questions.question: Within a minute of resuscitation, the newborn is now crying with a good colour and tone. Select two immediate actions.
questions.description:
Two immediate actions when the newborn is crying with a good colour and tone are:

Place the newborn with mother skin-to-skin.

Early breastfeeding.

answers.value: Place the newborn with mother skin-to-skin
Wrap the newborn and place it with a relative
Give antibiotics IV or IM
Early breastfeeding

questions.question: How do you prevent low blood sugar if the newborn has been resuscitated for more than one minute?
questions.description:
You prevent low blood sugar in the resuscitated newborn by:

Establish breastfeeding within the first half hour.

After breastfeeding give supplementary feeding in a cup

answers.value: Establish breastfeeding within the first half hour
After breastfeeding give supplementary feeding in a cup
Give the newborn cow milk
Give the newborn exclusive formula milk

keyLearningPointDetails.description: NR - Low birth weight and resuscitation

questions.question: How should you resuscitate a small or preterm newborn?
questions.description: You should resuscitate a small or preterm newborn in exactly the same way as full term newborn.

answers.value: In exactly the same way as for full term newborns
Only give 20 ventilations breaths per minute
Only perform resuscitation at a tertiary hospital

questions.question: What are the greatest challenges with regards to resuscitation of a small or preterm newborn?
questions.description:
The greatest challenges with regards to resuscitation of a small or preterm newborn are:

Adequate chest rise.

To ensure a correct seal of the mask and bag.

answers.value: Adequate chest rise
Disability
Sepsis/infections
To ensure a correct seal of the mask and bag

questions.question: What are important actions to take in order to provide successful inflation breaths?
questions.description:
Important actions to take in order to provide successful inflation breaths are:

Position the head parallel to the surface.

Sustain the breath for 2-3 seconds.

Make sure that chest raises with every breath.

answers.value: Position the head parallel to the surface
Sustain the breath for 2-3 seconds
Make sure that chest rasies with every breath
Assess the heart rate

chapters.content:
Respiratory Distress

At labour between 24 and 34 gestational weeks or estimated birth weight below 2 kg give the mother Betamethasone 12 mg IM twice.

OR

Dexamethasone 6 mg four times, 12 hours apart.

Severe Infection

If membranes rupture before gestational week 37 or more than 18 hours before delivery.

OR

If fever is higher than 38˚C before or during delivery.

Give her Ampicillin 1 g IV every 6 hours.

AND

Give the newborn Ampicillin 50 mg/kg IV/IM twice daily and Gentamicin 5 mg/kg IV/IM once daily for at least two days.

If the mother has HIV, hepatitis B, syphilis or tuberculosis follow national guidelines for treatment of the newborn.

Low Blood Sugar

If a newborn has asphyxia or danger signs:

  1. Keep the newborn warm by skin to skin contact with the mother.
  2. Start breastfeeding within half an hour and feed every 2 hours.
  3. If unable to suck give expressed milk 10 ml/kg in a cup or by nasogastric tube.
  4. If not possible or the newborn vomits give Glucose 10% 5 ml/kg/hour IV.

Assess the newborn with Apgar score 1, 5 and 10 minutes after birth.

Apgar 7-10: Healthy

Apgar 0-6: Requires medical attention
0 points
1 point
2 points
Activity
Limb arms and legs
Arms and legs flexed
Active
Pulse
Absent
Less than 100
Above 100
Grimace
No response
Grimace
Sneeze, cough
Appearance (skin colour)
Blue or pale
Body pink, arms and legs blue
All pink
Respiration
Absent
Slow, irregular
Crying
Total score

All newborns need routine care after delivery.

Avoid separating mother from newborn whenever possible and do not leave mother and newborn unattended at any time.

  • At delivery dry and stimulate the newborn. If not crying well or having difficulty breathing proceed to neonatal resuscitation.
  • Assess Apgar Score at 1, 5 and 10 minutes
  • Monitor the newborn closely.
  • Check the cord for bleeding every 15 min, keep it clean and dry. If bleeding, retie it.
  • Give 1 mg Vitamin K (IM).
  • Start breastfeeding within the first hour after birth and let the newborn feed on demand.
  • Examine the newborn, look for danger signs.
  • Apply antibiotic eye drops.
  • Give vaccines according to national guidelines.
  • Weigh the newborn, if less than 2.5 kg consider the newborn low birth weight and at risk of complications such as low blood sugar, respiratory distress and severe infections. Admit and monitor closely for danger signs, consider referral to a facility with advanced care.
  • The lower gestational age or birth weight, the higher the risk that the newborn is unable to suck adequately. Feed by cup or nasogastric tube. See action card for instructions.
  • If clinically stable manage with Kangaroo Motherhood Care: continuous and prolonged skin-to-skin contact with the mother or another caregiver. Initiate at the hospital and continue at home.

At discharge ask the mother to return if the newborn shows any danger signs.

Airway

Free and safe (no obstruction).

Breathing

Respiratory rate slower than 30 or faster than 60 per minute.

Cyanosis.

Severe chest in-drawings.

Grunting.

Apnoea (no breathing for more than 15 seconds).

Circulation

Signs of shock including:

Pale colour.

Weak pulse.

Heart rate below 80 or above 180.

Capillary refill time more than 3 seconds.

Disability

Poor feeding/inability to suck.

Irritability.

Convulsions.

Decreased muscle tone.

Decreased consciousness.

Vomiting.

Exposure

Temperature below 35.5°C or above 37.5°C.

Red, tender umbilicus.

Severe jaundice.

CALL FOR HELP!

Airway

Position so airway is free. Suction if obstructed.

Breathing

If no breathing, rub the back for 10 seconds.

If still no breathing or respiratory rate slower than 30 per minute: Start bag and mask ventilation.

Bluish colour or difficulty breathing with in drawings or grunting: oxygen by nasal catheter or prongs if available.

Circulation

If signs of shock give normal saline 10- 15 ml/kg IV.

Disability

If the newborn is drowsy, unconscious or convulsing:

  1. Measure blood glucose. If you cannot measure, assume low blood sugar and treat.
  2. If blood glucose is below 2.2 give Glucose 10% 2 ml/kg IV.
  3. Alternatively give expressed breast milk 10 ml/kg by nasogastric tube.
  4. If convulsions last more than 3 minutes or are brief serial seizures, give Phenobarbital 10 mg/kg IM/IV (max 40 mg/kg). Repeat if necessary.

See drug list for further treatment.

Exposure

  • Reheat the newborn, if axillary temperature below 36.5 C
  • Confirm severe jaundice with a bilirubin measurement and treat with phototherapy. If not available: Refer to facility with advanced care.
At any danger sign; suspect severe infection (sepsis or meningitis):

Give antibiotics Ampicillin and Gentamicin IV/IM according to age and weight.

If no improvement after 2 days, change to broader antibiotics, Ceftriaxone.

Drug dose of common drugs for newborns below one month of age.

Ampicillin

Age: Under 7 days

Administration: IM/IV

Dose: 50 mg/kg/dose x 2

Age: Above 7 days

Administration: IM/IV

Dose: 50 mg/kg/dose x 3

Ceftriaxone

Administration: IM/IV

Dose: 50 mg/kg/dose x 2

OR

100 mg/kg/dose x 1

Gentamicin

Age: Under 7 days

Weight: Below 2 kg

Administration: IM/IV

Dose: 1.5 mg/kg/dose x 2

Age: Under 7 days

Weight: Above 2 kg

Administration: IM/IV

Dose: 2.5 mg/kg/dose x 2

Age: Above 7 days

Dose: 7.5 mg/kg/dose x 1

Phenobarbital

Loading Dose

Administration: IM/IV/Oral

Dose: 10 mg/kg/dose x 1
repeat to max 40 mg/kg

Header!

BlueBerry!

Age
Fluid
(accumulated oral, nasogastric tube, IV)

2 days

  1. One
  2. Two
  3. Three

Do not refer if emergency is not controlled!

Never refer a patient with uncontrolled bleeding, retained placenta, uncontrolled hypertension, unevacuated septic or haemorrhagic abortion or septic shock.

Remove placenta by trained provider.

In cases of prolonged labour:
- If at a peripheral facility, refer the woman to a higher centre with her partograph for further management.

- At a referral facility, amniotomy may be done (also for HIV+ women if on antiretroviral therapy). Reassess in 2 hours and decide on further management if there is insufficient progress.

After emergency management and when in a stable condition, discuss decision of referral with woman and relatives.

Quickly organise transport and possible financial aid.

Inform the referral center.

Accompany the woman.

It is crucial that she is accompanied by a health worker who is trained in delivery care and able to manage an emergency situation, if it recurrs during transport.

Consider to bring a relative who can donate blood.

Bring

Referral note.

Essential emergency drugs:

  • Oxytocin and Ergometrine (alternatively Misoprostol) for treatment of postpartum haemorrhage
  • Oxytocin for IM injection immediately postpartum
  • Hydralazine for IV treatment of elevated blood pressure
  • Magnesium Sulphate for eclampsia
  • Calcium Gluconate for intoxication with Magnesium Sulphate
  • Ampicillin for infections
  • Diazepam for pain relief

Supplies:

  • Delivery set
  • Towels
  • IV-equipment + IV fluids
  • Foetoscope or Doppler
  • Blood pressure monitor
  • Ambu bag
  • Suction bulb

During Transport

Observe vital signs and level of consciousness.

If pregnant check FHR.

In case of excessive vaginal bleeding apply bimanual compression.

If the bleeding does not stop apply aorta compression (can be maintained up to 6 hours).

If the woman’s condition permits:

Keep record of all IV fluids, medications given, time of administration and the woman´s condition.

If in labour during transport:

FHR every half an hour.

If pushing and superficial breathing is not enough to repress this urge, stop the transport and deliver the woman.

drugDetails.content:
Indications and Usage

Ampicillin is a B-lactamantibiotics effective on gram positive as well as negative bacterial infections.

Dosage and Administration

Adults:

1 g intravenously every 6 hours (at sepsis initially each 4 hours).

Children:

First week of life:

50 mg/kg per dose every 12 hours intravenously or intramuscularly.

Week 2-4 of life:

50 mg/kg per dose every 8 hours intravenously or intramuscularly.

Contraindications

Allergy to penicillin.

Adverse Reactions

Common adverse reactions are diarrhea and skin rash.

Uncommon reactions are nausea, vomiting, stomatitis, glossitis, pseudomembraneous colitis, lowered platelets, anemia and urticaria.

Anaphylactic shock is rare.

Indications and Usage

For prophylaxis of ophthalmia neonatorum due to N. gonorrhoeae or C. trachomatis.

Sexually transmitted infections (STIs) including gonorrhea and chlamydia are a main cause of newborn eye infections (the newborn can get transmitted during delivery).

These infections can cause blindness if not treated.

Give antibiotic eye drops or ointment (e.g. Erythromycin Ophtalmic Ointment) to the newborn to prevent eye infections.

Dosage and Administration

For prophylaxis of neonatal gonococcal or chlamydial ophthalmia, a ribbon of ointment approximately 1 cm in length should be instilled into each lower conjunctival sac.

The ointment should not be flushed from the eye following instillation.

A new tube should be used for each infant.

For treatment of eye infection:

Do the following 6-8 times daily:

  • Wash hands with clean water and soap.
  • Wet clean cloth with boiled and cooled water.
  • Use the wet cloth to gently wash off pus from the baby’s eyes.
  • Apply 1% tetracycline eye ointment in each eye 3 times daily.
  • Wash hands.

Contraindications

None

Adverse Reactions

The most frequently reported adverse reactions are minor ocular irritations, redness and hypersensitivity reactions.

Indications and Usage

For lung maturation and prevention of respiratory distress and vertebral hemorrhage of the newborn at threatening preterm labour between 24 and 34 weeks gestation.

Dosage and Administration

12 mg IM, two doses, 24 hours apart (24 mg in total).

Contraindications

Active untreated infections.

Adverse Reactions

Common adverse reactions are mood changes and other mental disturbances, shortness of breath, edema and diabetic metabolism.

Indications and usage

Treatment of bacterial infections. Alternative to penicillin at allergy to penicillin.

Dosage and administration

Adults:

1-2 grams intravenously or intramuscular once daily.

Children:

For meningitis:

50 mg/kg per dose every 12 hours intravenously or 100 mg/kg per dose once every day intravenously or intramuscularly

For pus draining from the eye:

50 mg/kg/dose once intramuscularly (max 125 mg)

Contraindications

Allergy to cephalosporins. Severe reactions to penicillin (anaphylactic reactions)

Neonates ( ≤ 28 days):
Hyperbilirubinemic neonates, especially prematures, should not be treated with ceftriaxone.

In vitro studies have shown that ceftriaxone can displace bilirubin from its binding to serum albumin, leading to a possible risk of bilirubin encephalopathy in these patients.

Ceftriaxone is contraindicated in neonates if they require (or are expected to require) treatment with calcium-containing IV solutions, including continuous calcium-containing infusions such as parenteral nutrition because of the risk of precipitation of ceftriaxone-calcium.

Adverse reactions

Common adverse reactions are nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, skin rash, and itching.

Uncommon reactions are headache, dizziness, and urticaria.

Rare reactions are lowered platelets, necrosis of the skin, drug fever, candidiasis, hemolytic anemia and hearing loss.

Indications and Usage

For lung maturation and prevention of respiratory distress and vertebral hemorrhage of the newborn at threatening preterm labour between 24 and 34 weeks gestation.

Dosage and Administration

6 mg IM, four doses, 12 hours apart.

Contraindications

Active untreated infections.

Adverse Reactions

Vision changes, swelling, rapid weight gain, sleep problems (insomnia), mood changes, acne, dry skin, thinning skin, bruising or discoloration, slow wound healing, increased sweating, headache, dizziness, spinning sensation, nausea, stomach pain, bloating, muscle weakness, or changes in the shape or location of body fat (especially in your arms, legs, face, neck, breasts, and waist).

Rare instances of severe allergic reactions (anaphylaxis) have occurred in patients receiving corticosteroid therapy such as dexamethasone.

Indications and Usage

Aminoglycoside antibiotic indicated for treatment of severe or serious bacterial infections in adults and children.

Dosage and Administration

Adults:

240 mg intravenously once a day.

Children (First week of life):

2.5 mg per kg every 12 hours if term; 1.5 mg per kg every 12 hours if preterm intravenously or intramuscularly.

Treat for at least two days.

Children (Weeks 2-4 of life):

7.5 mg/kg per dose once a day intravenously or intramuscularly.

Contraindications

Allergy to aminoglycosides.

Treatment should not be more than 3 days if the patient is suffering from renal failure (oliguria or elevated creatinine).

Adverse Reactions

Common adverse reactions are kidney affection, hearing loss, and tinnitus.

Uncommon reactions are liver affection, increased or lowered blood pressure, respiratory depression, lowered platelets, joint and muscle pain, depression, coordination disturbances, skin rash, itching, visual disturbances, urticaria and anaphylactic reactions.

Rare reactions are deafness, hair loss, low urine production and necrosis of the skin.

Indications and usage

Oxytocin is a pituitary gland hormone.

Oxytocin injection is indicated to produce uterine contractions during the third stage of labor and to control postpartum haemorrhage.

Dosage and administration

Prevention of postpartum haemorrhage (for all women who have delivered):

10 units (1 ml.) of Oxytocin given intramuscularly immediately after delivery of the baby.

Treatment of postpartum haemorrhage:

20 units of Oxytocin added to 1 litre intravenous fluid (normal saline or Ringer’s lactate) given at fastest flow rate possible.

Continuing IV. dose:

Infuse 20 units of Oxytocin in 1 L. IV. fluids at 40 drops per minute.

Maximum dose:

Not more than 3 L of IV fluids containing Oxytocin.

Oxytocin is temperature sensitive and loses effectiveness after three months of storage at temperatures higher than 30 degrees Celsius (86 degrees Fahrenheit).

Store Oxytocin at a temperature between 2 and 8°C.

Contraindications

Hypersensitivity to Oxytocin.

Do not give Oxytocin as an IV bolus.

Adverse reactions

Common adverse reactions are cardiac arrhythmia, nausea, and vomiting.

Rare complications are severe water intoxication which can lead to convulsions and coma and even death, anaphylactic reaction and the loss of clotting factors (fibrinogen) in the blood leading to bleeding complications.

Indications and Usage

Phenobarbital is in a group of drugs called barbiturates.

Phenobarbital slows the activity of the brain and nervous system.

Phenobarbital is used to treat or prevent seizures.

Observe closely for apnoea and always have a bag-mask available to ventilate the child if necessary.

Be aware that the plasma half-life for Phenobarbital in children and newborns (less than 48 hours old) ranges between 60 to 180 hours with a mean of 110 hours.

Dosage and Administration

Children:

For seizures:

Start treatment with loading dose 20 mg/kg intravenously over 15 minutes or as a single dose intramuscularly if IV access is not established.

If convulsions do not stop within 30 minutes give further dose of phenobarbital 10 mg/kg IV slowly over five minutes (or IM.).

Repeat one more time after another 30 minutes, if necessary.

Maximum dose is of 40 mg/kg body weight.

If needed continue Phenobarbital at maintenance dose of 5 mg/kg per day.

CAUTION:

Diazepam given in addition to phenobarbital will increase the risk of circulatory collapse and respiratory failure.

Contraindications

Phenobarbital is contraindicated in patients who are hypersensitive to barbiturates, in patients with a history of manifest or latent porphyria, and in patients with marked impairment of liver function or respiratory disease in which dyspnoea or obstruction is evident.

Adverse reactions

Common:

The most common adverse reaction, estimated to occur at a rate of 1 to 3 patients per 100, are disorders of the nervous system such as drowsiness or sleepiness.

Less common:

Adverse reactions estimated to occur at a rate of less than 1 in 100 patients are listed below, grouped by organ system and by decreasing order of occurrence:

Nervous System:

Agitation, confusion, hyperkinesia, ataxia, CNS depression, nightmares, nervousness, psychiatric disturbance, hallucinations, insomnia, anxiety, dizziness, abnormality in thinking.

Respiratory System:

Hypoventilation, apnoea.

Cardiovascular System:

Bradycardia, hypotension, syncope.

Digestive System:

Nausea, vomiting, constipation.

Other Reported Reactions:

Headache, injection site reactions, hypersensitivity reactions (angioedoema, skin rashes, exfoliative dermatitis), fever, liver damage, megaloblastic anaemia following chronic Phenobarbital use.

Indications and Usage

Prevents bleeding complications in the newborn.

Dosage and Administration

1 mg given intramuscularly once, directly after birth, to all newborns.

Contraindications

None.

chapters.content:
Intravenous access is used to administer fluids and drugs.

Equipment for intravenous/intramuscular access should be located in the delivery room.

It should be available at all health facilities for adults as well as children.

It includes:

Antiseptic solution to clean the surrounding skin, syringes, intravenous cannulas, venflons, a stasis hose/band, tapes and cannulas.

Adults:

The grey and green cannulas have a large diameter.

Using them makes the fluid enter the body more rapidly.

Children:

For insertion of an intravenous cannula in the neonate select a suitable vein to place the cannula or a gauge 21 or 23 butterfly needle.

Peripheral vein:

  • Identify an accessible peripheral vein, see illustration.
  • An assistant should keep the position of the limb steady and should act as a tourniquet by obstructing the venous return with his or her fingers lightly closed around the limb. Alternatively use a stasis hose/band.
  • Clean the surrounding skin with an antiseptic solution (such as spirit, iodine, isopropyl alcohol or 7+ % alcohol solution), then introduce the cannula into the vein and insert most of its length. Fix the catheter securely with tape. Apply a splint with the limb in an appropriate position (e.g. elbow extended, wrist slightly flexed).

Scalp Vein:

These are often used in children ages less than 2 years but are most suitable in young infants.

  • Find a suitable scalp vein (usually in the midline of the forehead, the temporal area or above or behind the ear).
  • Shave the area if necessary, and clean the skin with an antiseptic solution. The assistant should occlude the vein proximal to the site of puncture. Fill a syringe and leave the end of the tubing open. Introduce the butterfly needle as described above. Blood flowing back slowly through the tubing indicates that the needle is in the vein.
  • Care should be taken not to cannulate an artery, which is recognised by palpation. If there is a pulsatile spurting of blood, withdraw the needle and apply pressure until the bleeding stops; then look for the vein.

A nasogastric (NG) tube provides access to the stomach and its contents.

NG tubes can also be used for enteral feeding of infants.

It also enables you to drain gastric contents, decompress the stomach, obtain a specimen of the gastric contents, or introduce a passage into the GI tract.

All necessary equipment should be prepared, assembled and available at the table prior to starting the nasogastric tube.

Basic equipment includes:

  • Personal protective equipment
  • NG tube
  • Catheter tip irrigation 60ml syringe
  • Water-soluble lubricant, preferably 2% Xylocaine jelly. Alternatively use water.
  • Adhesive tape
  • Stethoscope
  • pH indicator strips

Insertion of a nasogastric tube:

  • Holding the tip of the tube against the child’s nose, measure the distance from the nose to the ear lobe, then to the xiphisternum (epigastrium). Mark the tube at this point.
  • Hold the child firmly. Lubricate the tip of the catheter with water, and pass it directly into one nostril, pushing it slowly in. It should pass easily down into the stomach without resistance. When the measured distance is reached, fix the tube with tape at the nose.
  • Aspirate a small amount of stomach contents with a syringe to confirm that the tube is in place (if available check that it turns blue lithmus paper pink). If no aspirate is obtained, inject air down the tube and listen over the abdomen with a stethoscope.
  • If there is any doubt about the location of the tube, withdraw it and start again.
  • When the tube is in place, fix a 20 ml syringe (without the plunger) to the end of the tube, and pour food or fluid into the syringe, allowing it to flow by gravity.
  • If oxygen therapy is to be given by nasopharyngeal catheter at the same time, pass both tubes down the same nostril and try to keep the other nostril patent by wiping away crusts and secretions, or pass the feeding tube through the mouth.

questions.question: What are the most common causes of death amongst newborns?
questions.description:
The most common causes of death amongst newborns are:

Preterm birth

Asphyxia

Infections

answers.value: Preterm birth
Asphyxia
Infections
HIV

questions.question: Which statement is true?
questions.description: Most newborn deaths are avoidable, true.

answers.value: Most newborn deaths are avoidable
Most newborn deaths are not avoidable

questions.question: When do most newborn deaths occur?
questions.description: Most newborn deaths occur within the first week of life.

answers.value: Within the first week of life
Within the first 2-4 weeks of life
After the first month of life

questions.question: How do you prevent respiratory distress in newborns at preterm labour (GA 24-34 or estimated birth weight below 2 kg)?
questions.description: You prevent respiratory distress in newborns at preterm labour (GA 24-34 or estimated birth weight below 2 kg) by giving the mother betamethasone or dexamethasone.

answers.value: Give the mother betamethasone or dexamethasone
Give the mother antibiotics
Perform a caesarean section

questions.question: What is the correct dose and administration of betamethasone?
questions.description:
The correct dose and administration of betamethasone is:
12 mg IM twice with 24 hours apart

answers.value: 12 mg IM twice with 24 hours apart
12 mg IM every 12 hours
24 mg IM once
24 mg IM twice with 24 hours apart

questions.question: What are the maternal risk factors associated with newborn infection?
questions.description:
The maternal risk factors associated with newborn infections are: 

Preterm prelabour rupture of membranes (PPROM) 

Prelabour rupture of membranes (PROM) more than 18 hours before labour

Intrapartum fever

Foul-smelling vaginal discharge

answers.value: Preterm prelabour rupture of membranes (PPROM)
Prelabour rupture of membranes (PROM) more than 18 hours before labour
Intrapartum fever
Foul-smelling vaginal discharge

questions.question: How do you prevent newborn infections if risk factors are present?
questions.description:
To prevent newborn infections if risk factors are present, you:

Give antibiotics to the mother.

Give antibiotics to the newborn.

answers.value: Give antibiotics to the mother
Give antibiotics to the newborn
Perform a caesarean section
Perform Active Management of Third Stage of Labor

questions.question: What is a newborn who has been resuscitated at risk of?
questions.description:
A newborn who has been resuscitated is at risk of:

Low blood sugar

Respiratory distress

Seizures

answers.value: Low blood sugar
Respiratory distress
Urinary tract infection
Seizures

questions.question: A newborn has been resuscitated successfully and is stable. What are the next actions?
questions.description:
A newborn has been resuscitated successfully and is stable. The next actions are:

Ensure early breastfeeding. 

Keep warm by skin to skin contact with the mother.

Monitor closely for danger signs.

answers.value: Ensure early breastfeeding
Keep warm by skin to skin contact with the mother
Monitor closely for danger signs
Wrap to keep warm and give the newborn to a relative

questions.question: What is meant by “early breastfeeding”?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/breastfeeding
questions.description: “Early breastfeeding” means breastfeeding initiated within 30 minutes of birth.

answers.value: Breastfeeding initiated within 30 minutes of birth
Breastfeeding initiated after 2 hours of birth
Feeding by nasogastric tube

questions.question: Which newborns need initial care after delivery?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/dry_newborn
questions.description: All newborns need initial care after delivery.

answers.value: All newborns
Those at risk of infection
Asphyxiated newborns
Those born in thick meconium

questions.question: After delivery and stimulation, a newborn is not crying or breathing well, what do you do?
questions.image: /key learning points/Active management of third stage/brand_new_baby
questions.description: If a newborn is not crying or breathing well after delivery and stimulation, proceed to neonatal resuscitation.

answers.value: Proceed to neonatal resuscitation
Counsel the mother on her loss
Place the newborn skin to skin with the mother
Hope that spontaneous breathing starts

keyLearningPointDetails.description: Initial care of the newborn actions

questions.question: Initial care of the newborn (above 1 kg) includes amongst others which of the following?
questions.description:
Initial care of the newborn (above 1 kg) includes amongst others the following:

Check breathing and colour every 15 minutes.

Check heart rate and temperature every 15 minutes

Give 1 mg vitamin K (IM).

answers.value: Check breathing and colour every 15 minutes
Check heart rate and temperature every 15 minutes
Give 1 mg vitamin K (IM)
Give Ampicillin and Gentamicin IM/IV

questions.question: A newborn is delivered prematurely and weighs less than 2.5 kg. What do you do?
questions.description:
If a newborn is delivered prematurely and weighs less than 2.5 kg, you do the following:

Resuscitate if necessary.

When stable keep in skin to skin contact with mother and initiate breastfeeding.
Admit and monitor closely for danger signs while ensuring skin to skin contact with the mother is maintained.

answers.value: Resuscitate if necessary
Wait and see if it survives
When stable keep in skin to skin contact with mother and initiate breastfeeding
Admit and monitor closely for danger signs while ensuring skin to skin contact with the mother is maintained.

questions.question: A preterm newborn is unable to suck adequately what should you do?
questions.description:
If a preterm newborn is unable to suck adequately, you:

Feed by cup or nasogastric tube.

Consider referral to facility with advanced care.

answers.value: Feed by cup or nasogastric tube
Give antibiotics
Provide counselling to the mother, the newborn is unlikely to survive
Consider referral to facility with advanced care

questions.question: Which statement is true?
questions.description: The signs of serious illness in newborns are difficult to identify - true.

answers.value: The signs of serious illness in newborns are difficult to identify.
The signs of serious illness in newborns are easy to identify.

questions.question: What is meant by “danger signs” with regards to newborns?
questions.description: “Danger signs” with regards to newborns means signs of serious illness.

answers.value: Signs of serious illness
Signs indicating that the mother is not able to care for the newborn

questions.question: What does management of “A, B, C” stand for?
questions.description: Management of A, B, C stands for Airway, Breathing and Circulation.

answers.value: Airway, Breathing, Circulation
Assess, Breathing, Circulation
Airway, Breast-milk, Circumcision

questions.question: An unconscious newborn is brought to the clinic. Place the following actions in the correct order:
questions.description:
An unconscious newborn is brought to the clinic. The correct order of the actions is:
1. Call for help!
2. Manage Airway
3. Manage Breathing
4. Manage Circulation

answers.value: Call for help!
Manage Airway
Manage Breathing
Manage Circulation

questions.question: What do you need to observe when assessing “A” for Airway in management of A, B, C?
questions.description:
When assessing “A” for Airway in management of A, B, C, you need to observe:

If airway is obstructed.

If airway is free and safe.

answers.value: If airway is obstructed
If airway is free and safe

questions.question: What are the breathing danger signs in newborns?
questions.description:
The breathing danger signs in newborns are:

Respiratory rate slower than 30 per minute or faster than 60 per minute.

Severe chest in drawings.

Grunting

answers.value: Respiratory rate slower than 30 per minute or faster than 60 per minute
Seizure
Severe chest in drawings
Grunting

questions.question: A newborn has a respiratory rate below 30 breaths per minute, what do you do?
questions.description: If the respiratory rate is below 30 breaths per minute, start bag and mask ventilation.

answers.value: Start bag and mask ventilation
Place it skin to skin with the mother
Start to administer antibiotics

questions.question: What is grunting in a newborn?
questions.description: Grunting is when the newborn’s chest is moving unnaturally and the newborn has a sound on its breathing.

answers.value: The newborn’s chest is moving unnaturally and the newborn makes a sound while breathing
It is crying due to being hungry
It is pale due to being cold
It is red due to fever

questions.question: What is apnoea in a newborn?
questions.description: Apnoea in a newborn means that the newborn is not breathing for more than 15 seconds.

answers.value: No breathing for more than 15 seconds
Respiratory rate faster than 60 per minute
Respiratory rate less than 30 per minute
Capillary refill time more than 3 seconds

questions.question: What are the signs of shock?
questions.description:
The signs of shock in a newborn are:

Pale colour and weak pulse.

Heart rate below 80 or above 180.

Capillary refill time of more than 3 seconds.

answers.value: Pale colour and weak pulse
Heart rate below 80 or above 180
Capillary refill time of more than 3 seconds
Crying loudly

questions.question: If a newborn has a heart rate of 200 and pale colour what is it showing signs of?
questions.description: If a newborn has a heart rate of 200 and pale colour, it is showing signs of shock.

answers.value: Signs of shock
Signs of respiratory distress
A normal newborn
Signs of wanting to breastfeed

questions.question: Which of the following are danger signs in a newborn?
questions.description:
The following are danger signs in a newborn:

Poor feeding or inability to suck.

Decreased consciousness.

Vomiting.

answers.value: Poor feeding or inability to suck
Decreased consciousness
Passing meconium after delivery
Vomiting

questions.question: Which of the following are danger signs in a newborn?
questions.description:
The following are danger signs in a newborn:

Convulsions.

Decreased muscle tone.

Irritability.

answers.value: Convulsions
Decreased muscle tone
Irritability
Signs of wanting to breastfeed

questions.question: Choose the danger signs of exposure in a newborn.
questions.description:
The danger signs of exposure in a newborn are:

Temperature below 36.5˚C or above 37.5˚C.

Red tender umbilicus.

Severe jaundice.

answers.value: Temperature below 36.5˚C or above 37.5˚C
Red tender umbilicus
Severe jaundice
Gestational age above 37 weeks

questions.question: What is severe jaundice in a newborn?
questions.description:
Severe jaundice in a newborn is:
A yellowish tone that appears on the face during the first day of life or extends to the palms and soles at any time.

answers.value: A yellowish tone that appears on the face during the first day of life or extends to the palms and soles at any time
A yellowish tone that appears on the face and extends to the palms and soles during the first day

questions.question: A newborn is two weeks old, the mother says it is not feeding well, the heart rate is 200 and it has a capillary refill time of 4 seconds. Place the following actions in order:
questions.description:
A newborn is two weeks old, the mother says it is not feeding well, the heart rate is 200 and it has a capillary refill time of 4 seconds. The correct order of the actions is:

1.     Call for help and make sure airway is free and safe. If obstructed, suction. 
2.     Start bag and mask ventilation if the newborn is not breathing or has a respiratory rate of below 30 per minute.
3.     Give fluid therapy, 10ml per kg normal saline intravenously over 10 minutes. Repeat if necessary.
4.     Give first dose of antibiotics and consider referral to facility with advanced care.

answers.value: Call for help and make sure airway is free and safe. If obstructed, suction.
Start bag and mask ventilation if the newborn is not breathing or has a respiratory rate of below 30 per minute.
Give fluid therapy, 10ml per kg normal saline intravenously over 10 minutes. Repeat if necessary.
Give first dose of antibiotics and consider referral to facility with advanced care.

questions.question: You suspect that a two-week-old newborn has an infection but are not quite sure. What do you do?
questions.description: If you suspect that a two-week-old newborn has an infection but are not quite sure, you act fast and treat on little suspicion.

answers.value: Act fast and treat on little suspicion
Admit to monitor further
Ask the mother to return if the newborn is getting worse

questions.question: A newborn has an obstructed airway, what do you do?
questions.description: If the airway is obstructed, position so airway is free and use suction.

answers.value: Suction
Give chest compressions
Ventilate

questions.question: A newborn has a bluish colour and difficulty breathing. What do you do?
questions.description: If a newborn has a bluish colour and difficulty breathing, you give oxygen by nasal catheter or prongs if available.

answers.value: Give oxygen by nasal catheter or prongs if available.
Give glucose 10% by Nasogastric tube
Wait and see if the respiration normalizes spontaneously

questions.question: A newborn is drowsy and unconscious. What do you do?
questions.description: If a newborn is drowsy and unconscious, you check blood glucose. If you cannot measure, assume low blood sugar and treat.

answers.value: Check blood glucose. If you cannot measure, assume low blood sugar and treat.
Counsel the mother on the loss of her newborn
Encourage breastfeeding

questions.question: What is the correct treatment of low blood sugar in a newborn?
questions.description:
The correct treatment of low blood sugar in a newborn is: 

Give 10 % glucose 2 ml per kg IV. 

Alternatively give expressed breast milk or glucose 10 ml per kg by nasogastric tube.

answers.value: Give 10 % glucose 2 ml per kg IV.
Alternatively give expressed breast milk or glucose 10 ml per kg by nasogastric tube
Give 10 % glucose 10 ml per kg in nasogastric tube

questions.question: A newborn is having convulsions for more than 3 minutes. The blood sugar is 1.5. Place the following actions in order:
questions.description:
A newborn is having convulsions for more than 3 minutes. The blood sugar is 1.5. The correct order of the actions is:

1.     Give 10 % glucose 2 ml per kg IV. Alternatively give expressed breast milk or glucose 10 ml per kg by nasogastric tube.

2.     Phenobarbital 20 mg per kg IV or IM. 

3.     Give first dose of antibiotics.

4.     Consider referral to facility with advanced care.

answers.value: Give 10 % glucose 2 ml per kg IV. Alternatively give expressed breast milk or glucose 10 ml per kg by nasogastric tube
Phenobarbital 20 mg per kg IV or IM
Give first dose of antibiotics
Consider referral to facility with advanced care

questions.question: A newborn is having convulsions and you cannot measure blood glucose. What should you do?
questions.description:
If a newborn is having convulsions and you cannot measure blood glucose, you do the following:

Assume low blood sugar and treat.

Give Phenobarbital 20 mg/kg IV/IM.

Consider referral to facility with advanced care after providing initial care and stabilizing the newborn.

answers.value: Assume low blood sugar and treat
Refer immediately to facility with advanced care
Give phenobarbital 20 mg/kg IV/IM
Consider referral to facility with advanced care after providing initial care and stabilizing the newborn

questions.question: What is the maximum total dosage of Phenobarbital for a newborn?
questions.description: The maximum total dosage of Phenobarbital for a newborn is 40 mg/kg.

answers.value: 40 mg/kg
60 mg/kg
100 mg/kg

questions.question: If the newborn has jaundice what should you do?
questions.description:
If the newborn has jaundice, you do the following:

Confirm with a bilirubin measurement and treat with phototherapy.

Refer to facility with advanced care.

answers.value: Confirm with a bilirubin measurement and treat with phototherapy
Refer to facility with advanced care
Place the newborn without clothes under the sun

questions.question: A newborn has a temperature of 36 degrees. What do you do?
questions.description: If a newborn has a temperature of 36 degrees, you warm up with skin to skin contact with mother and check for danger signs.

answers.value: Warm up with skin to skin contact with mother
Check for danger signs
Ventilate with a bag and mask
Give 10 % glucose 2 ml per kg IV. Alternatively give expressed breast milk or glucose 10 ml per kg by nasogastric tube

questions.question: You should suspect a severe infection and give antibiotics to a newborn if:
questions.description: You should suspect a severe infection and give antibiotics to a newborn if there are any danger signs at all.

answers.value: There are any danger signs at all
There are three or more danger signs
The mother is concerned about her newborn

questions.question: If the newborn’s condition does not improve within 2 days what should you do?
questions.description: If the newborn’s condition does not improve within 2 days, you should change treatment to broader antibiotics, usually Ceftriaxone 100 mg per kg IV or IM once daily.

answers.value: Change treatment to broader antibiotics, usually Ceftriaxone 100 mg per kg IV or IM once daily
Stop antibiotic treatment and discharge for care at home
Administer oral antibiotics instead

questions.question: A newborn with danger signs is at risk of low blood sugar. How would you prevent this?
questions.description: A newborn with danger signs is at risk of low blood sugar. To prevent this risk, you keep the newborn warm by skin to skin contact with the mother and increase feeding frequency to every 2 hours.

answers.value: Keep warm by skin to skin contact with the mother
Increase feeding frequency to every 2 hours
Let a relative breastfeed
Give 10% glucose IV

questions.question: If a newborn is unable to suck, how can you administer expressed breastmilk?
questions.description:
If a newborn is unable to suck, you can administer expressed breastmilk?

In a cup.

By nasogastric tube.

If expressed milk is not possible or the newborn vomits give glucose 10% 5 ml per kg/hour (IV).

answers.value: In a cup
By nasogastric tube
By letting a relative breastfeed
If expressed milk is not possible or the newborn vomits give glucose 10% 5 ml per kg/hour (IV).

questions.question: Your facility is rural and has limited treatment options, and a newborn is brought in with danger signs. What should you do?
questions.description: If your facility is rural and has limited treatment options, and a newborn is brought in with danger signs, you should give a first dose of antibiotics and refer urgently to a facility with advanced care.

answers.value: Give first dose of antibiotics and refer urgently to a facility with advanced care
Admit the newborn and monitor closely
Give first dose of antibiotics and ensure that the mother returns the next day

questions.question: What is kangaroo motherhood care?
questions.description: Kangaroo motherhood care is continuous and prolonged skin-to-skin contact with the mother.

answers.value: Continuous and prolonged skin-to-skin contact with the mother
Carrying the newborn in a bag that is placed on a caregiver’s stomach
